author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Four Years or More with Basal Cell Carcinoma Lesion
content: Hi kswife, Basal cell carcinomas can be very slow growing tumors.There are sub-types which also differ in their aggressiveness. Usually, these are slow growing, 'locally' invasive malignant tumors but rarely metastasize.   The incidence of distant metastatic basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is very rare— 0.003% to 0.5% of the population.  Large, neglected, ulcerated, locally invasive and uncontrolled tumors are most prone to metastasize . Metastases usually occur after multiple local recurrences.  Therefore,it is mandatory to treat BCC promptly and adequately and to have regular followups to avoid the risk of metastasis to regional lymph nodes or distant sites(The lymph nodes, lung, bone, skin, spleen, and brain are sites of metastasis).  If excision (preferably Mohs') is successful, then perhaps, one only needs to be follow up regularly and carefully. Best wishes!

title: Re: melanoma of the big toenail
content: Hi, Any pigmented lesion under the nail or proximal nail fold must be viewed with suspicion. The chances of it being a subungual melanoma (a type of Acral lentiginous melanoma)  is higher if... - one is one belongs to certain ethnic groups(asian or black),  - over 60 years of age.or - if the lesion is under the big toe nail or the thumb nail. (Majority of subungual melanomas (90%) occur on the thumb or   the great toe). Good luck!

author: bdaycake  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Nov 12, 2008 12:42 pm Gender: Female
title: how do i keep myself safe?
content: Ever since all the risk factors for skin cancer were made known to me (at least 5 years ago), I have tried to be really cautious with my skin and sun exposure. I have blonde hair, really light blue eyes, very fair skin, and lots of moles and freckles. And it took a lot of trial and error to realize that only SPF 50 sunscreen keeps me from getting burnt. Well, the only thing I didn't have was family history, except for my great aunt.  Well, last year my dad was diagnosed with melanoma. He caught it very early and luckily didn't need any chemo or radiation. they just removed a huge chunk of skin, so now he has a big scar on his chest. The only problem, the melenoma was not at all "textbook", if you know what I mean. It was three small red freckles on his chest. He just got them checked out because he never saw them before, but the dermatologist who looked at it just wanted to biopsy it anyway, but assured him that it was probably not melenoma. Well, it was. So basically, I have learned that it's not just the ABCD thing that determines melenoma.  So now I'm a bit scared. My dad hardly went out in the sun without loads of sunscreen. He grew up in canada too, and never really went to the beach or pool. I have been to the beach every summer of my life for vacation and grew up where it's a lot sunnier. I have been burnt a lot more than him.  I'm pretty sure I don't have any serious skin anomolies right now, just some round freckles, a few "beauty mark" type moles on my back and shoulders. But it's kid of hard to keep track of what was there before and what is there now. I guess I'm just really scared that I'll end up with three small red freckles too and not even notice if they were there before or not. Most of my freckles/moles are on my back, and shoulders, places I can't see very well.  I just turned 18 and my parents before didn't want me to get a skin cancer screening just yet, but I plan to get one as soon as I can. But my main question is how can I be sure that my skin is fine? It seems to me that skin cancer is inevitable for me and I don't want to find out too late. My dermatologist (for acne, about a year ago) recommended a routine skin cancer screening once a year, is that enought to keep me safe? I don't know, maybe I'm just being paranoid, but I don't want to catch anything too late. Any help on how to stay safe, if there is anything more to do, would be greatly appreciated. Thanks lots.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: how do i keep myself safe?
content: Hello,  In absence of randomized studies that provide definite standard methods or recommendations for screening and early diagnosis programs for malignant melanoma, many physicians agree that highest risk individuals (e.g. those with a strong family history of melanoma) should follow frequent self-examination and annual professional (primary care physicians or dermatologists) skin evaluation.   The screening examination is done with a source of bright light and a magnifying lens. It takes a few minutes, is safe and allows visualization of areas that are difficult to be seen by self examination like the back and posterior legs.  Some dermatologists use a dermoscopy (microscope like) that may improve the visualization and the evaluation of a pigmented lesion.   There is no recommend age for starting the screening program and you better follow up with your doctor for better evaluation and to be reassured.  Hope you find this information useful. Please keep us updated. Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Mon Nov 17, 2008 4:34 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: Sebaceous cyst changing
content: Hello,  This sounds like the cyst you have in your back is infected and inflamed. When inflammation occurs it becomes more swollen, red, painful and tender (abscess like). The skin around may feel warm and you may have a low grade fever.  This can be improved if you follow local antiseptic measure and apply local antibiotic ointment.  If this will not improve the condition, you should follow up with your doctor, who might prescribe systemic antibiotics or recommend its removal or drainage accordingly.  I would advise you to follow up with your doctor and to discuss with her your concerns.  Please keep us updated. Best regards.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: Re: Seroma will not drain
content: Hi lizabeth1973, A seroma is essentially a collection of fluid near the surgical site. These often resolve with the contents being reabsorbed by the body, after a few weeks time. Generally speaking the seroma itself does not pose a risk of infection although repeated attempts at aspirating the fluid does increase the risk. I hope this is helpful. Best wishes. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

I also experienced excessive sweating on my scrotum when I am outside. This caused extreme itchiness and it is very warm around that area. The itchiness does not only restricted to the areas with the cyst.  May I know all these problems are due to Sebaceous Cysts? I heard that by applying a heat pad to these cysts will be able to cure the cysts. Is it true? If not, surgical removal of all 30+ cysts seems like a tough job.  Thanks in advance for any advices offered.
posted_time: Post  by guy82 » Tue Apr 01, 2008 3:02 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Multiple Sebaceous Cysts on Scrotum
content: Hello, You are right that squeezing these cysts will only compound the problem since it creates a wound in an are that is typically full of bacteria.  Most cysts will resolve on their own when left alone but in rare cases of multiple and large cysts, excision might be necessary to avoid further infection of surrounding tissues.  You should see a dermatologist who can remove them if needed or advise you otherwise.  For home care of the cysts, use an antibacterial soap and bathe regularly with it.  Apply warm, wet washcloths to the lumps for 20 to 30 minutes, 3 to 4 times a day. If you prefer, you can also use a hot water bottle or heating pad over a damp towel. The heat and moisture can soothe the lump, increase blood circulation to the area, and speed healing.  If by chance you are not eating a healthy diet, important in preventing and healing infections, you should be certain to take a vitamin to help.  Vitamin A, C, the Bs and Zinc are all important in healing so a daily multivitamin might be a good idea.  You may be experiencing other problems relating to the excessive sweat such as a yeast infection but it is unlikely caused by the cysts.  Yeast overgrowth occurs in a warm, moist environment such as the groin and can cause itching as you describe but can be treated with over-the-counter topical antifungal creams and powders.  Keeping the area as clean and dry as possible will help prevent future outbreaks.    Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi JMan81,  I would recommend you see your doctor.  Skin cancer can cause the skin to bleed but usually there are other changes that can be seen with the cancer as well.  Some of your medines, the ace inhibitor and particularly the Tegretol, can cause platelet problems that can lead to increased bleeding.  Your doctor can do a CBC to look at the platelet numbers and some other tests to look at your ability to clot.  Also, if your liver is not functioning well it may not be able to make some of the needed clotting factors to keep you from bleeding (or more appropriately, stop you from bleeding).  I would look for something like this before being too concerned about skin cancer.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Imissmom,  I don't have any pictures to show you but I can tell you what we look for when determining if a mole is concerning.  A good way to remember these characteristics is using the ABCDE mnemonic.  A=asymmetry.  A mole that is different on one side than the other is more concerning.  B=Borders.  A mole with irregular borders rather than smooth borders is more concerning.  C=Color.  A mole with multiple colors is more concerning than one with a uniform color.  D=diameter.  A mole greater than 6mm is more concerning.  E=elevation or evolution.  A mole that is raised is more concerning.  A mole that is changing is more concerning.  The more of these characteristics that a mole possess the more concerning it is for being melanoma.  Best wishes.

title: Seborrheic Keratosis, Acanthotic Variant, Potential trouble?
content: Greetings:  A couple of weeks ago, I noticed some dark areas and a raised, jagged spot on my husband's back.  Husband is 41.  No previous surgeries.  I talked him into going to a dermatologist for consult, and after shave biopsy of three (3) spots, the diagnosis was Seborrheic Keratosis, Acanthotic Variant.  Pathology goes on to say:  "In each sample, levels through the tissue designated "x,y, and z" are examined on one slide.  Sections demonstrate a seborrheic keratosis, acanthotic variant, characterized by acanthotic expansion on the epidermis with variable keratin cyst formation.  There are no malignant features identified as sampled.  H and E stained preparations are utilized in the evaluation.  The microscopic findings support the diagnosis."  My question is this:  to a layperson, this sounds like a great diagnosis, but I have Googled all this and have proceeded to alarm myself that this could potentially be pre-cancerous?  Is this a firm diagnosis of benign origin?? Is there anything else I should ask his physician? posted_time: Post  by BrandiWyne » Tue Jun 12, 2007 10:43 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Seborrheic keratoses are benign lesions of the skin.  They are often darker than the surrounding skin and have a raised appearance to them.  It's almost as if they are glued on.  Acanthosis is a condition that basically is very similar and involves thickening of the skin.  It, too, is a benign process.  There is another condition known as actinic keratosis.  These lesions are considered precancerous and should be treated to prevent them from becoming skin cancer.  They can be easily frozen with liquid nitrogen by your doctor.  These spots generally are less raised and have a more rough feel to them, almost like sand paper.  I would recommend you have your doctor take a look at the spots to see if they look like actinic keratosis or a variant of seborrheic keratosis.  Seborrheic keratosis (any of their variants) will only very rarely develop into skin cancer-mostly they are just annoyances.  Best wishes.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Smartpatrol9, I respect that you have been educated enough to recognise that it is of great value to use licensed technicians and estheticians for your body art.    Techniques employed by the artist should include "aseptic technique" which is a means of creating an environment that reduces the risks of infection.  The licensed provider has been specially trained to know how to do so.  The use of a new needle is a critical component, as well as proper cleaning or sterilization of other associated equipment.  Equally important is hand washing and the ink supply itself.  You have not indicated if the tattoo site is reddened or hot to touch, if the needle site is oozing at all, or if you are having a fever, or increased pain at the site.. These are all possible indicators of a localized infection.  Nausea that passes on its own (that you state seems triggered by your thinking about the possibility of infection) is not typically linked to a skin related infection - in the absence of other signs.   If any of these signs manifest, I would ask my primary physician or a local urgent care center to evaluate you and make appropriate recommendations.  If your friend is a good artist - I would also recommend that you strongly suggest they get a license so that they may continue to practice their art safely, for his/herself - and for the client.

content: Hello,  This would be very difficult to tell over the internet.  It could simply be postinflammatory hyperpigmentation. These are localized, macular, dark hyperpigmentation at site of a previous inflammation. They occur at any age and are a reaction to trauma (physical or chemical injury), skin irritation, or dermatoses. They maybe associated with an inflammation of skin because of underlying injury or condition at the initial time of occurrence.  Call the doctor that examined you and tell him about your concerns. If he tells you he thinks you shouldn't worry about it then all that will be required is to keep an eye on them from time to time. From your description it does appear that they are harmless. author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Outrider,  There is no replacement for direct clinical examination, But according to your description,  It could be a condition known as Fordyce spots .  Fordyce spots are not infectious and their cause is unknown. They are abnormally dilated blood vessels, covered by thickened skin. They can appear on the glans, shaft or scrotum. They may be solitary, but frequently appear in crops of 50 to 100. They are usually small (1-5mm) in size and may present as bright red or purple papules, painless and are not itchy.  Fordyce spots usually affect younger men. They may cause embarrassment because of their appearance, or a fear that they might be sexually transmitted. They may bleed if injured or even during intercourse.  Although a number of approaches have been tried, there is no simple, reliable treatment to remove them. Troublesome bleeding spots can be sealed with a device that uses a small electric current (electrocautery).  Only by complete history and physical examination, the correct diagnosis can be reached.   Hope you find this information useful.  Best regards,

I also had a neck x-ray done recently for neck pain, and it did not seem to show up on the films.    What should I look for in regards to lymph nodes, and should I be concerned about this mass?  Possibly get another opinion?    Thanks for your time.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear tiggersprings,  It is probably a Lymph node as it occurs in a Lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician.   Palpation is the first step to confirm the presence of a Lymph node enlargement.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter.   Abnormal Lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).   Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.   The postauricular Lymph nodes (if my guess is correct according to your description) are located behind the ears. They drain the external auditory meatus, pinna, scalp. Common causes of enlargement include local infection.   You did not mention where the excised melanoma was. If it is in the drained area of this lymph node, then it should be taken seriously for more investigations. In such cases the nodes are from firm to hard in consistency.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.   A Conventional US study with or without Doppler can help in confirmation of the nature of this swelling. CT scan also would confirm the presence of a Lymph node.   The personal and medical history as well as the clinical examination gives a good idea about the possibility of this node to be of malignant Origin. Further investigations include, US, CT scan and FNAC or biopsy.  Hope you find this information useful. Do not forget that, here is no replacement to a direct clinical examination. Only by complete history and physical examination, the correct diagnosis can be reached.   Best regards.

title: Shave Biopsy on suspected Melanomas ....?
content: I had two lesions.  One on my back, one over my stomach. The dermatologist's PA-C stated the one on my back was large, very black and had a red "halo" around it as though it were inflamed or irritated.  She then immediately performed what I thought were "SHAVE" biopsies on both lesions and covered them with tiny, circular band-aids.  The one on my back was not entirely covered by the dressing.  I was left with circular depressions of raw areas that have now formed scabs.  I've since read that if malignant melanoma is suspected, shave biopsies should never be performed, but I can't find the reason why this is.  Could someone answer this for me?  My results came in today as both being "BENIGN," and the fact that a shave biopsy was indeed performed, was confirmed.  Without my saying anything much, the tech went on to say, "Amy's real good at shave biopsy's, she got the entire lesion, didn't she?"  I didn't know how to respond to this.  Should I now be comfortable with a "benign" diagnosis even though I know shave biopsies were performed on suspicious, pigmented lesions?  Could someone please, pretty please, take the time to answer these two questions?  Thanks.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Befallingdusk, Different types of biopsies can be done to diagnose  a suspected melanoma. The preferred one is excisional biopsy since the whole layers of the skin can be chesked to see the exact tumor thickness which is a very important prognosti factor for cutaneaous melanoma. In shave biopsy, the epidermis and the most superficial part of the dermis are shaved with a surgical blade. it is not generally recommended if a malignant melanoma is suspected. An exception is in the case of lentigo maligna in which the the risk of misdiagnosis is higher if deeper biopsies are taken, a broad, paper-thin shave biopsy is prefrred. An expert dermatologist can recognize lesions that are more likely to be malignant and would recommend excisional biopsy. Congratulations that the pathology results in bengin lesions. Good luck,

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi birdy, most lumps and swellings are benign. Frequent causes of skin lumps of the back are sebaceous cysts, lipomas, skin cancer, abscess, and melanoma. Skin cancers, including melanoma, have different behaviour and appearance from the lump you described. An abscess is painful, and develops in a few days, and has distinct manifestations, others that the one you had.  Lipomas are the most common benign tumors of the body; they are growth of fatty tissue cells and can develop in almost any organ of the body, but most commonly in the subcutaneous layer (fat) just below the skin. They grow slowly and are nonpainful. Sometimes, depending upon where in the body and what surrounding tissue or organ the lipoma has affected, they may swell and grow until inflammation goes away.  Other common cause of lumps in that site are sebaceous cysts, also called epidermal or epidermoid cysts. Sebaceous cysts most often arise from swollen hair follicles and are usually found on the face, neck, and trunk (back). They are slow-growing, painless lumps beneath the skin. At times, they may become inflamed and tender.  There are other less frecuent causes of back lumps, and most are noncancerous. I believe it is a lipoma or other benign tumor. But as always, the pathologist has the last word. Good luck.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Melanoma
content: My apologies for the delay in your getting a response to your question.  There has been a backlog of questions here at The lounge.  We are endeavoring to respond to all questions, including old ones.  As more of us are responding to questions, we hope to be able to respond to new questions in a timely manner.   Retreatment with interferon can be done, especially if it worked the first time it was tried.  Without knowing the specifics of your case, it is difficutl  to answer your questions with specifics.  Retreatment with interferon may not be as successful as the first time or may not last in its benefit as the first time.  The standard does to use is not 100% certain, although the literature would suggest that higher doses give better initial responses, but that the toxicity of higher doses can be difficult to tolerate.  The long-term benefit of high doses versus lower doses is not 100% clear.  Have you been evaluated for any type of vaccine study?  I don't know if your situation applies to such a study, but it would not be unreasonable to explore that option.  There may also be various clinical trials looking at experimental drugs that could be next options for you.  The larger hospital systems have such trials.  My best to you.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

title: Radiodermatitis
content: My apologies for the delay in your getting a response to your question.  There has been a backlog of questions here at The lounge.  We are endeavoring to respond to all questions, including old ones.  As more of us are responding to questions, we hope to be able to respond to new questions in a timely manner.  I hope that you will visit The Lounge again and that you next experience here will be better than your last.  I would suggest that you speak with a Dermatologist or a cancer specialist whom specializes in the skin.  regarding your question about spontaneous cures of cancer, that is something that doesnot tend to ccur in the vast majority of patients.  However, there have been reports ofver the years of such occuring.  Many cancer doctors have had a patient now and then with a cancer that has appeared to disappear with treatment.  For most of those patients, the cancer really is not gone, but only with a residual microscopic area that cannot be seen, only later to grow and to reappear.  However, sometimes a recurrence does not occur.  Perhaps there is something with the body's immune mechanisms that kicks into gear.  There is a lot about this topic that is not understood.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

title: Cannot find source of melanoma.
content: A surgeon found a tumor on my dad's small intestine while operating to correct an ulcer. The biopsy of the tumor "supports a diagnosis" of melanoma. However, the source of the melanoma on the skin cannot be found.   How common is this that the source cannot be found?  The oncologist noted on the request for scans that the reason was colon cancer. This may be a stupid question, but can colon cancer also be melanoma?  Thank you for your time.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Melanoma
content: My apologies for the delay in your getting a response to your question.  There has been a backlog of questions here at The lounge.  We are endeavoring to respond to all questions, including old ones.  As more of us are responding to questions, we hope to be able to respond to new questions in a timely manner.  I hope that you will visit The Lounge again and that you next experience here will be better than your last.  Sometimes the primary site of origin of a melanoma cannot be found.  Melanomas can arise in areas other than the skin.  There is an interesting phenomenon seen in some cancers, including melanomas, in that the sites that have spread to other areas of the body can feedback and cause the original site not to grow and thus not be detected.  Also, there is a phenomenon seen in some cancers, including in melanoma,in  that the immune mechanisms of the body may be able to deal with the primary site of disease but are not able to deal with the sites that have spread.  There is still a lot not known about why some cancers spread but the original site cannot be detected easily or readily.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Fearful, I viewed the link to the web page and in my opinion I would put very little faith in one who has no medical backround not to mention that it is incorrectly posted information. Breast cancer and prostate cancer is the most commonly "diagnosed" cancer. However, the "death rate" from lung cancer exceeds both and kills more men and women. To discourage breast self exams is ridiculous, as this is sometimes the reason for many women being diagnosed at an earlier stage. Initially because of their different or abnormal findings. The reason different types of cancer are being diagnosed is because of better technology. As for discouraging any biopsy, types of cancer are identified, and the best treatment options for that particular type of cancer are initiated. As for the question "about believing this guy" I don't.  As for your other post about bacitracin. Bacitracin ointment is an antibiotic/bacteriocide that is absorbed in "minimal" amounts through normal skin (not large open areas from burns etc.) and causes no harm, unless of course one is allergic to the drug. The reason substances may be absorbed through the skin is because of its vascular nature. The only true overdose with the medication bacitracin (not the ointment based which by the way is never taken internally) is with the intramuscular or intraveneous form which use has been mostly replaced with such medications as  penicillins, cephalosporins, and vancomycin. I hope this was helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi there, It's always difficult to diagnose swellings and lumps without examination. I would therefore advise you to get an appointment with your doctor. It sems from what you say that it is a callus type lump (a corn). This can be the result of wearing tight shoes. It could also be a wart which is caused by a viral infection (human papilloma virus). Treatment is usually very simple using salicylic acid preparations.

posted_time: Post  by FranklinePen » Mon Aug 16, 2004 9:20 am

author: helping hands  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Jan 24, 2005 7:32 pm Location: nurse
title: Home sunlamps
content: To reply to your comment, I don't think there is much difference between home sunlamps and tanning beds. Any time there is more exposure to harmful effects of the sun's rays even if they are man made, the body has a negative reaction to it. I think that you should limit your amount of exposure to these lamps and make sure that you provide yourself with the necessary protection with sunscreen of spf of 15 or higher. You should also try washing your face with Phisoderm or another gentle soap. This helps with acne. And don't scrub your face hard. Wash gently because scrubbing will more than likely make your face break out further. You can also try using non-comedogenic make-up products. (They won't clog your pores.) How bad is your acne, and does stress cause it to flare up? I would avoid these sun lamps until they have been studied further. I worry about skin cancer with the use of these lamps and that is much worse than having acne that will change once your hormones decide to settle down. Hope this helps.

author: fearuvhorses  Guest Posts: 13 Joined: Tue Jun 10, 2003 7:57 pm Location: Alberta, Canada
title: Malignant Melanoma - Heart Disease - A Link?
content: Is there a link between a new diagnosis of malignant melanoma (excised - borders clear) and worsening angina?  Does the presence of one change the outcome of the other?
posted_time: Post  by fearuvhorses » Sat Mar 27, 2004 1:42 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Malignant melanoma - heart disease - A link?
content: Dear Fearuvhorses,  If you mean that there is a causal link between angina and malignant melanoma. i have not heard of one.  The most famous relation between malignant melanoma and heart disease is that malignant melanoma is notorius for sending metastases to the pericadium (membrane surrounding the heart).  So, if a patient has chest pain and history of malignant melanoma, i would suggest doing an echocardiogram to see whether there is any pericardial effusion (fluid) surrounding the heart which will be an indication of this possibility.  If this patient is known to have coronary disease, a new diagnosis of malignant melanoma could have put a stress on this patient and hence precipitating a new attack of angina.  The prognosis of malignant melanoma is actually determined by the depth in the skin to which it has grown not by the surgical margins and whether the tumour has metastasized to any where else.  If malignant melanoma has metastasized to distant organs, the prognosis is usually bad as most of malignant melanomas do not respond well to treatment whether chemotherapy or radiation.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
